commentBody:
Every year, around this time, I remember to be thankful.

I am thankful for puzzles. These wonderful conundrums allow me to pause and explore truth, beauty, and knowledge. I have always enjoyed the mental gymnastics required to unravel such enigmas, and reading the comments here reminds me I am less alone in my pursuit. Puzzles are alive and well.

I am thankful for the constructors themselves. Solving, and appreciating, a crossword is like beholding a radiant canvas, painted by artists who decided to share their gifts with the world (just don't give them the brush-off; that wouldn't be palette-able). I am encouraged by the creativity of these cruciverbalists and the hope and delight they provide.

I am thankful for the columnists here who reflect upon these puzzles and help shape this special community. Moreover, I am thankful for writers everywhere who remind us of our humanity and encourage us regularly to lead with peace, grace, and love.

I am thankful for wordplay, whether well-worn or punderated. I would even go see a performance on the history of lexicography; that would really be a play on words.

And I am thankful for all of you and for how much love and kindness exists in this humble space. I exhort you to continue to brighten the world however you feel called. Empathy can still be cool.

With best wishes for a happy holiday season, filled with plenty of pie and puzzles!

Mike

(PS: Please pass the rolls! I feel butter already.)

My nerdy family tree has square roots.

(Some parts are real; some parts are imaginary. It's really complex.)
I‚Äôd put AOLER in the same category as ETAIL as words that only exist in crosswords.
I feel like the rebus would have been better and more obvious if "one" wasn't one of the options... Two to four and three to nine were much more fun and impressive.
It's a good thing Deb didn't have to write the column today. We know she was told there would be no math.
AOLER? Is this what we‚Äôve come to?
Well done theme today!

Ways I plan to use this puzzle during tomorrow‚Äôs Friendsgiving (my favorite holiday):

Pies and more pies: all that sugar blasting through the old KREBS CYCLE!

Pies of course fit the theme here because pi are squared.

LEMON TARTS? Just another way to do Pie.

Saving ‚ÄúI FEEL YA‚Äù for my pals groaning over too much pie.

Time to batten down the hatches and fire up the hurricane lamps.  

I suspect villagers with pitchforks and torches are on the way.

Let them come.  I liked it.  I thought it was a great idea, and well executed.  Nobody can harsh my buzz...oh, who am I kidding...I have no buzz left.

Thank you, Mr. Liebeskind.

This was a fabulous puzzle. I'll even forgive AOLER. 

Using ONE as one of the rebuses was a nicely confusing trick. I had promptly put in WISHBONE and left the rest blank. A few crossers later, I realized it was WISHB(ONE)FORMATION, and (ONE)DGE worked great, so I promptly solved YEARO(FOUR)LORD, but couldn't figure out the across. Same with SATUR(NINE). Down nailed, but couldn't figure out the across. 

Then the penny (nickel???) dropped with the revealer. Or maybe in the admittedly overdue currency overhaul, the I should thank the revealer for the dime?
too many letters to fit in one tiny box. awkward theme. Hated it.

I‚Äôm not sure how I feel about this.  On the one hand, double rebuses are just plain mean.  On the other hand, there was a good sense of flow, some really good long words, and some damn good cluing. 

Well done.
If that clue for SHORTSTOP looks familiar to you, it should. We had substantially the same clue for it in Nov. 8.  And yes, it‚Äôs still baseball!
Well SATUR(3)^2 is a new word for me.

This was a fine puzzle with some nice clues and a twisted rebus.  I got taken in by the fact that the two parts of the first rebus were ONE and the same, not two different numbers, and didn‚Äôt catch on to the squaring concept until I got the revealer.  WISHBONEFORMATION was a gimme for me, as were the other sports clues, although it took me some time to get SHORTSTOP (great clue) because I had vee instead of HEE for a bit. TIL what the KREBSCYCLE is.  

I just want to wish all of my puzzling friends and colleagues the happiest of Thanksgivings.  It‚Äôs my favorite holiday because it‚Äôs all about food, family and friends and provides a noncommercial respite before the frenzy of the December holidays.  With my daughter,  her husband and our grandson living in Scotland, and my wife‚Äôs family in Missouri, California and Florida, it will be a quiet one for us, but we are fortunate to be able to share it with a dear friend whose family is not available to him this year.

On one hand, the execution of the theme was brilliant, especially the cross of Earth Re-entry and Saturnine (for a sec I was looking for some phrase that had eighty-one imbedded in it).

On the other, the cluing and the fill felt oddly uneven, with several in the gimme variety (Elba, for example, or Yabba) -- Mon-Tues level, and then there was Krebs Cycle. The shortstop clue echoed one we encountered In a very recent puzzle, and so lost its novelty -- hardly its own fault; I lay that one at the feet of the editors. 

But the theme was so beautifully done!

Glad I didn't have to enter both numbers in that circle to get the gold, that would have been tedious, especially since I'm no fast worker. 

These days a lucky scientist is one who a) hasn't had their grant canceled, b) is still employed, c) hasn't been deported, d) doesn't work for, or rely on, the CDC, EPA, FDA, NIH or NSF...
I got stuck trying to figure out the ending of DISCO_ _ _ _ _ and how a lucky scientist could be dancing.
MY FIRST SUCCESSFUL REBUS! So happy

I really hate rebuses that don't permit all reasonable variations. I finally gave up and hit reveal (surprise! it's a number puzzle but no combination of digits will work! you have to spell them out!). Cute concept but the juice was not worth the squeeze...
LOVED how clever this one was, thankful for finally being able to grasp a Thursday puzzle without hints‚Ä¶ for once ü•≤
I knew that someday all the painful hours I spent memorizing the KREBSCYCLE for AP biology would come in handy.
I solved the puzzle, but digital users don‚Äôt get credit because they can‚Äôt fit 3 letters/numbers in one square.
Ohhhooo that was a good one when the hint finally clicked!!
Very happy with today‚Äôs puzzle. Clever, understandable, and inoffensive rebus. Clicked well with the fill, too.
I am totally enamored with this puzzle. The rebuses were a blast and I love that one was included as its own square. Not to mention lots of great fill. This was a delight and so satisfying to solve.

Speaking of squaring the circle, we just completed 25,000 nautical miles at sea while sharing a 300 square foot space for eight years. Proof that all a pirate needs is a stout vessel and a trusted first mate! Arrgh! Happy Thanksgiving! ü¶úüè¥‚Äç‚ò†Ô∏èü•ß
Got the long entry down below relatively early, but clunky rebus marred the overall experience (even though it was clever). Another to be solved preferably on paper.

I‚Äôll put myself in the positive category for this one; I enjoyed it, but I‚Äôll have some sympathy for the naysayers. WISHBONEFORMATION is a pretty arcane sports term, although gettable from the clue; KREBSCYCLE a pretty arcane biochemical term, and only gettable from the crosses if you aren‚Äôt familiar‚Äîbut pretty fair crosses except maybe for ODEON which is bread and butter to experienced cruciverbalists but maybe not to newer solvers. And, there‚Äôs math.
But I thoroughly enjoyed the theme and thought the theme entries were fresh and interesting. I LOVED the misdirect that the first rebus was the same up and down but not the others; that absolutely sold the puzzle for me.
And for all you rebus haters out there, that‚Äôs cool, but if your issues are technical I say again, don‚Äôt try to shove ‚Äúthree/nine‚Äù in the circle or whatever, just put in one number and do the rest in your head, it‚Äôll save you a headache and eye strain.

Very nice one! I didn‚Äôt truly understand the gimmick until I filled in my very last squares, which were the squares. The gold star appeared at the exact moment the light bulb went on in my brain. Thanks, Alexander Liebeskind!
Didn‚Äôt get the trick until I was almost finished. Loved it!
Just want to chime in and say that I really enjoyed this puzzle. It's exactly what I look forward to for a Thursday challenge.
thoroughly thursday
Today's puzzle is #2500 in my streak. And that's a square. Coincidence? I don't think so.

Welcome, Ms Kagan. It's lovely to see you here and hopefully for a long and distinguished tenure.  We may get fractious (rarely) but we all love solving. Why else would we be here?

Just don't ask what the plural of OCTOPUS is, ans you'll be fine.
I entered the rebuses as (e.g.,) 3/9 and so on - unacceptable.  Works for me and I will claim it as a win although it won't go into records as one.

I thought a rebus was acceptable if just the first letter was entered, but "O", "F", and "N" didn't work, nor did "O", "T", and "T". Had to spell out the root numbers, which finally worked. (Not sure if spelling out the squares would have worked as well, but still - not in keeping with rebus rules, at least as I've always understood them.)
Thanks for mentioning Maryam Mirzakhani. What a life! Gone too soon.

Mr Liebeskind provides a graceful acknowledgement to Maryam Mirzakhani, the great Iranian mathematician who was the first woman to win the Fields Medal. She died age 40.
Her story is told in the lovely documentary, 'Algebra's Daughter' (2019). I remember seeing it then and my recollection is that it's pretty non-mathist friendly. If you can find it, watch it.

Eerier and eelier!

Happy turducken, tofu loaf, or whathaveyou.

Ella Fitzgerald, Idris ELBA, LEMON TARTS, and double rebuses. What's not to love?
Peace to all.

Is it a words-only puzzle? Not today.  

All in all a fun puzzle  But I think allowing numerals in the rebuses would be a bit more elegant.
Very, very clever. This is the kind of trickiness I love in a Thursday puzzle.

I am thankful for rebi, math, the KREBS CYCLE, Alexander Liebeskind, Eleanor Kagan (loved ‚ÄúAsk Me Another‚Äù) and Joan Armatrading, whose album SQUARE THE CIRCLE contains ‚ÄúTrue Love,‚Äù which is what I am most thankful for: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vTVin57Zkus Keep loving one another . . .

I am thankful for rebi, math, the KREBS CYCLE, Alexander Liebeskind, Eleanor Kagan (loved ‚ÄúAsk Me Another‚Äù) and Joan Armatrading, whose SQUARE THE CIRCLE contains ‚ÄúTrue Love,‚Äù which is what I‚Äôm most thankful for: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vTVin57Zkus Keep loving one another . . .
I was amused that we had EERIER just a few days after we had EELIER.

I'm sorry to report that today's puzzle is invalid.

1^^2 = 1x1

We have recently found utterly disputable evidence* that 1x1 = 2.

I was going to provide a link, but I did a Google search for "Terrance Howard 1x1 = 2" and I got so many hits that seemed receptive that I went into a fugue state.  

So I'll just have to leave you to google it, if you have the stomach.

*it's not, it's not.  1x1 = 1....OMG it's not...*inconsolable sobbing*

I enjoyed this, even if I found it a bit too easy with the circles. Personally I think it would have been a more fitting Thursday challenge if we were required to find the rebus spots ourselves.

Some of the trivia I had to get from crosses but no lookups were necessary. Well, ok, I did use Google to check one thing once I had filled the grid only to be presented with the "So close" pop-up:

Not knowing American football I had entered fISHB(ONE)FORMATION. Of course, the cross of RAfER looked weird, but I've seen stranger words in NYT puzzles (Wordle defeated me once with the word "primp", which looks like a letter salad to me - unlike the town of Szczebrzeszyn or the illness rze≈ºƒÖczka ü§£). Still, knowing I had an error somewhere, I went back to that spot. I stared at RAfER and the clue "More cold and wet". Nothing came to me, and I still liked fISHBONE... I was so stumped I actually googled the formation in the end. WISHBONE... D'oh! Still, I don't like that clue for RAWER. Is it about steak? If not, what? And if it is about steak, that's the most unappetizing way to describe a rare one that I've seen in my life.
How can you complete an online crossword, when squares require more than one letter? Ridiculous.

Oddly enough‚Äîor Jungianly enough? I suppose this is synchronicity‚ÄîI was reading about Saturn last night. I‚Äôm in the middle of ‚ÄòThe Colossus of Maroussi,‚Äô and just a few hours ago I closed the book before going to bed right after Henry Miller‚Äôs long philippic on the poor planet. He was detailing his impressions of seeing it through the telescope of an observatory in 1939 Athens: ‚ÄúWhen seen through a magnifying lens, [Saturn is] impressive to the layman in a way which the scientist must instinctively deplore and deprecate. No facts or figures about Saturn, no magnification, can explain the unreasonably disquieting sensation which the sight of this planet produces upon the mind of the spectator.‚Äù Miller then goes on‚Äîand on‚Äîto detail the particulars of his ‚Äúdisquieting sensation.‚Äù I didn‚Äôt want to quote the full paragraph here because, well, it‚Äôs Henry Miller and chaste as this book of his happens to be, his reflections of Saturn are a bit depressing. But oh, so spellbinding, too, because, well, it is Henry Miller. If you‚Äôd like to read the rather long paragraph, I found it quoted in its entirety here in an archive of an old Seattle radio station: https://www.krabarchive.com/ralphmag/GH/saturn-miller-reading.html I wasn‚Äôt sure I was going to like the puzzle because the initial down clues across the top all solved like a Monday, but then Thursdayness happened, accompanied by really interesting entries in the rest of the grid‚Äîand I loved it. Happy Tofurkey Day, everyone!

This just felt fun, in an easy but clever way. I wasn‚Äôt chewing down my finger nails going over and over all the clues, I wasn‚Äôt looking up the info. I was playing, in the ‚Äúflow,‚Äù and thankful for this new crossword way of thinking I seem to have developed over the last six months. 

As usual I learned some words (ODEON, SED), and some trivia (the TITANS lost to the Olympians, WISHBONE FORMATION is a thing, RHOS are the symbols for density in physics‚Ä¶. but since I passed Physics 101, did I know this 25 years ago?) 

My favorite clue was 60A, ‚ÄúChecks someone‚Äôs checks?‚Äù
I have a small bone to pick with the coder(s) of today's puzzle - I wish the 4mation would have allowed digits in the squared circles. Oh well... Happy Thanksg151ng!
Loved this. I generally don‚Äôt like revised/rebi, but this puzzle was great. Thanks to the constructor.
So much for lingering over a Thursday puzzle on a day off. This was Tuesday/Wednesday stuff.

This may have been the first time I correctly spotted (and figured out) the rebus, so that was exciting!

3D had me imagining an alternative world in which the disco ball was DISCOVERED by some lucky inventor with a penchant for partying. His name? DISCOdEREk
It was my understanding that there would be no math
Cool theme but undercooked. So many puzzles recently where the solve leads to some clues reading nonsensically. Makes them ugly and unsatisfying. Rest of the fill was pretty breezy for a Thursday
Gobble gobble!
Enjoyed this fun puzzle, thanks!!

My first time spotting a rebus and inserting the rebus - for SATURNINE - no less. A word I've never used but somehow knew. I also somehow knew about KREBS, another word I've never used. 

Such a good crossword! 

Sending Thanksgiving wishes to my niece and her family in Elon, North Carolina. I hope one day to spend it with them.
Absolutely loved it.  Probably my favorite Thursday puzzle ever‚Ä¶just the right amount of trickery.

Not gonna lie I thought the revealer had something to do with pi. I had worked out the 9d needed a four in the rebus to make sense, and the other two rebuses I had squared away as one and 3. But I didnt let ego get in the way I circled back and an audit revealed i had made an error in my maths. Upon re-entry I was able to complete the puzzle. Luckily im a fast worker and was able to finish under my usual time

For those wondering what this puzzle has to do with Thanksgiving, it‚Äôs obvious.  SATURNINE means ‚Äúglum‚Äù which is sandwiched by the same letters in ‚Äúgrim‚Äù, the ending to ‚ÄúPilgrim‚Äù.  Duh!

And wishes for a splendid Thanksgiving to all in the tribe here, for whom I'm extraordinarily grateful.

Wow! Science and rebus united.
Got dinged by emus, so will try again

The key parts of the Krebs-Rebus cycle: A series of panicked reactions that break down winning streaks to generate energy carriers (HUH? , SNAFU, NO WAY! U2?) and release FE SEES as a solver-generated posting product. It begins when a puzzle molecule (Across Down) joins multiple molecules to start the Krebs-Rebus cycle, which then goes through Dante's circles of infernal reactions to produce highly active oppositional subscibers and regenerates the fourth-day-of-the-week choler molecule for the next round.¬†

Further research is needed.

And yes, this little solver has made her homemade pumpkin pie filling, piecrusts, and cranberry sauce, loves a good Rebus, and wishes everyone a safe and peaceful holiday.

Finished the crossword.  Then Mini, Wordle, Connections.  Got the pangram.

Finally, came back here and figured out the trick.

Where's the turkey?

I enjoyed this puzzle and had fun solving.   But it occurred to me how the various baseball clues referenced in NYT puzzles must be so difficult for the foreign solvers.  Imagine if we Americans saw clues about Cricket.  I am guessing we would be stumped.  Haha!

Very nice. I got the theme quickly enough, and then I realized it wasn't sufficient to help me solve, and I got angry at Alexander Liebskind and at myself, but mostly at Alexander Liebskind, but then I realized it was the depth of my understanding that was insufficient, and through this realization it became sufficient, and my love for Alexander Liebskind grew by leaps and bound.

ONE was the first rebus I filled in, which led me to believe that the other rebuses would work for across and down ‚Äì what a terrific misdirect!  I see from earlier comments that I was not alone.

I am one who has trouble saying RAWER once, let alone five times fast.

I liked the backward subtheme, with a backward SODA to go with ‚ÄúCoke-versus-Pepsi‚Äù, a backward GAH to go with OLD, and a backward ELBA to go with FAST WORKER.  Serendipity at its finest.

Alexander‚Äôs notes gave me a highly worthwhile TIL ‚Äì Maryam Mirzakhani, the first woman to win the prestigious Fields Award, the highest honor in mathematics, and the first Iranian to do so.  I found the Wikipedia article on her to be very inspiring.

Here‚Äôs something you don‚Äôt see very often in a symmetrical grid ‚Äì and it‚Äôs because of the theme ‚Äì one answer each of length 12, 13, 15, and 17.

So, Alexander, you brought me many extras on top of a splendid solve, for which I‚Äôm most grateful.  Thank you!
Nice. And I thought I was terrible with numbers. : ))

You know what‚Äôs freaky? If you take the square-root of the answers that I put in the circles, they work for the across clues. Our constructor is sure a lucky mathematician.

Also, the Saturnians called: 43A is insultingly geocentric.

As I stated yesterday, I loved this puzzle. Loved loved loved loved loved this puzzle. Loved it. I am ever so grateful to Alexander as well as all constructors for providing my favorite pastime each day. And I truly look forward to this forum everyday. 

Happy Thanksgiving, Crosslandia ü•∞
Help! What do you do when your fill is perfect, checked against the key, but doesn't recognize the solve?
Thankful¬≤

Oh, yes, this was good!! Needed help with the double rebus - I never seem to see them. Thanks, Alexander! A great way to start the day. I hope y‚Äôall have a wonderful Thanksgiving. ü¶ÉAnd if this day is hard for you, may you feel some peace.
Typical Thursday.  Even after reading the explanations and comments, I still don't get it.

Fun theme, but I really really HATE it when the biggest challenge to a puzzle is having to try out multiple ways of filling in the dang rebus to get the software to accept it. Does it want both numerals? Just the one you get by squaring? Numerals or spelled out? There's nothing fun about that, it's just irritating. Spoils the effect. Could you maybe code it to accept all of the above?
Spare me the complexity of multi-letter squares.  And what happened to the monthly theme puzzle?

Off topic for the puzzle, but not the day. Some people watch football today. I listen to Alice's Restaurant, watch the Macy's Day parade, and rewatch The West Wing Thanksgiving episodes. Here are some excerpts. https://youtu.be/vH-J94gQMow?si=-8J2esVdQ9aH5l9M https://youtu.be/luTzmLiVC4I?si=XS1kJVBDxBKqUl2I

Next level Thursday trickery with the number spelled out as a rebus in the across answer being squared and completing the down entry.  Wow.  Mind-blowing.

Also, thanks so much to the constructor for honoring Maryam Mirzakhani in his comment.  A brilliant mind lost to us much too soon.

There's a meme out there that says the real Krebs Cycle is learn the Krebs Cycle <-->forget the Krebs Cycle. I've memorized and forgotten it three times in the course of my education. I'm thankful not to have to again.
Wowwww love it
Outstanding!  I solved ONE and TWO/FOUR but didn‚Äôt suss out the theme, so the revealer was a pleasant surprise that let me quickly add THREE/NINE.  KREBS CYCLE was a nice bonus.
dare i say one of my favorite puzzles this year???????

How to get even with Alexander?  Wish canned cranberry sauce on him into Eternity?  No; that would be too cruel!  
Just kidding; he's always a pleasure--inventive and fun.
9D was the early giveaway.
38A was the biggest groaner.
24D was the Best Word.
35A was My New Word.
4D was ....GAG! UGH!  GAH

Alex, your puzzle was Neato!
Circles? Squares? On Thanksgiving? Am I the only one who was thinking pi(e) r-squared?

Whew (again). Tough one for me at first and was appropriately puzzled for a while. But finally tumbling to the trick was the big turning point. Still had to stop and ponder at each rebus square but then it would dawn on me. This ended up being a very enjoyable solve. One puzzle find today. A Tuesday from May 5, 1981 by Janke. Four 15 letter theme answers in that one. SQUAREDACCOUNTS SQUARETHECIRCLE GETSASQUAREDEAL And then... the one often appropriate for us: BACKTOSQUAREONE Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=5/5/1981&g=24&d=A Might put another puzzle find in a reply. ....

(If you missed this because of Thanksgiving, don't.¬† Go back to it at some¬†point.)

My first question was: Will there be a 1 in every circle?¬† Or will there be different numbers?¬† But I didn't know the half of it.¬† Or rather the square of it.

1 is a brilliant way to start this because the square of 1 is 1.¬† No tip-off.

It took the revealer for me to see it.¬† I had FAS(2)RKER, but couldn't fill in 9D.¬† And after I had the squaring trick, I had SATUR(9), but couldn't figure out what EAREIGHTYONENTRY was supposed to be.

I had it bass-ackwards, didn't I?

A great theme idea, marvelous construction, and lots, lots, lots for the solver to have to figure out.¬† A perfect Thursday.¬† Into my Puzzle of the Year list it goes.¬† Nice job, Alexander!
--

The Krebs cycle still haunts me after I nearly failed a physiology class my freshman year. (Naive violinist, only non pre-med student in the class.) Full of admiration for all those folks who aced the exam and probably have spent the intervening 50 years healing humanity!
Since this was a "numbers" theme, it was too bad numbers weren't accepted in the Rebus answers. A lot easier to fill in.

It amuses me whenever NYT crossword clues refer to AOL users as "early" users of the internet. The Internet started in 1983 (ARPANET in 1969), and AOL users didn't have meaningful access to it until 1995. 

I had been using it for a few years by then, (and didn't consider myself an early user), so I remember when the unwashed masses of unsophisticated AOL users were heralded as the beginning of the end of the Internet.

A pedantic bit of old-timerism, but if I can't indulge in that here, where can I? Usenet is no more ....

This was definitely a fun math-based theme! Maybe not the first time that the weirdness in Across entries is not the same as the weirdness in Down entries.

No doubt I have an error somewhere, but ... I solved the puzzle pretty fast yet never got the ghost of Mr. Happy Pencil despite scanning the grid about six times now and even comparing it with an answer key.

I'm extremely thankful for this clever crossword, and for this wonderful community!

However, on the off-chance that Thanksgiving falls on a Thursday again next year, I'd like to see a puzzle with TURKEY in all the rebus squares using all the common phrases that contain that word. To wit:

DecaTUR KEYring.

DecaTUR KEYboard.

I gave a non sequiTUR KEYnote speech to the American Absurdists And Octopi Association Of America, and boy are my arms tired.

Why is AtaTURK EYeing me like a custard-filled turnip?

Is thaT UR KEY lime pie in the banana hammock or are you just happy to see me?

And of course the revealer would be AC/DC's classic chart-topper "Daddy's Got a Turkey in the Oven(Let's not Baste It)".


Happy Turkey Day, y'all!!

24 down. Why?! I kept looking up words trying to find out what could possibly mean gloomy as an atmosphere and had to read the article to see that it‚Äôs Saturn Nine and since three is the square root of nine then three is the answer for the rebus. In what world does any of that make sense? Saturn 9 is synonymous in what way with being gloomy as an atmosphere? I am way too literal for some of these. I should complain because I got much further on today‚Äôs puzzle without needing help than the three previous puzzles this week.  How, I have no idea. Anyhow. Happy Thanksgiving everyone.

Wth is a YEAROtwoLORD?? That's the answer I received for the rebus square when I asked for a reveal (because I can't do rebuses in the phone app, despite someone showing me how she can do it on her phone app.) I'm a bit disappointed.
Roger Ebert's critique of North described this puzzle for me. Oh well. Cheers.
Appropriately for Thanksgiving, this was easy as pie. Or, more appropriately for the puzzle perhaps, it was as easy as 1 2 3. Enjoy your green bean casserole!

Well, I got a Thursday PB today, but I did so without fully grokking the theme, and IMO I *should* have been held up for another couple minutes due to my rebus entries, which clearly reflected an incomplete grasp of the theme.

I correctly had ONE and THREE for two of the themers (without having understood why THREE would work as a suffix for SATUR), but for the last one I had FOUR‚Ä¶and I was quite surprised (almost startled, actually) to get a gold star rather than the ‚Äúget ye to thine flyspecking‚Äù message when I filled in the last square.

Unpopular opinion: the rebus validation semantics are too permissive! I don‚Äôt see why anything other than ONE, THREE, and FOUR (along with O, T, and F) should have been considered correct here, and I fee cheated out of the extra couple minutes that I should have been forced to spend puzzling over my half-baked theme answers.

That said: great theme, and a very fun little thanksgiving Thursday. Thanks, Alexander!
Very clever use of the rebuses. I could predict before I got to the comments that this would be divisive. :-)

I love a rebus puzzle!  A double rebus?  Double the fun!

As for the rebus haters, I say, "Give 'em time.  They'll learn to love them, too."

But I pity the poor NYT techies, who have to figure out in advance all the way we solvers are going to try to put the rebi into the grid.
Still, with a number-rebus, it would've been nice if we could've put in numbers.  And it would've made the finished puzzle that much prettier.

Hey!  No complaints on Thanksgiving.  Instead, it's time to be grateful!
And I am grateful for the puzzle, for its constructors and editors, and for this, our extended Wordplay family.

Happy Thanksgiving, y'all!

Incredible theme! Congratulations Alexander Liebeskind. 

I once knew every step of the Krebs Cycle. Today I'm grateful just to recall the name for the xword.

Happy Thanksgiving to American solvers, and Happy Ordinary Thursday to everyone else.

Theme was fun, unfortunately the theme words were so well 'protected' by difficult trivia or challenging clues that I couldn't get close enough to solve it without hints.

This was a difficult theme that would have been way better if there were more theme words and if 2 of the crosses weren't niche trivia, the 3rd having a 5 letter rhebus.

And 2 of the theme words were fairly obscure.

I wish this theme were in an approachable puzzle because it was clever.

I was in autocheck mode because it is Thursday, after all. I put in the TWO and hit enter too quickly by mistake. I can't fix it, and the puzzle won't let me be done - the timer keeps going. sigh. Any ideas?

From all reports this is a words-only puzzle as entering numbers will not get you the gold.  But entering numbers would have made this a traditional rebus, not just a crossword rebus, so I think in that spirit the numbers should have been acceptable entries. A quick scientifical factoid that in no way invalidates the clue/answer pair at 31D. 

The KREBS CYCLE (I prefer to call it the tricarboxylic acid cycle or citric acid cycle, and this has been the trend for a few decades now...) is in no way "essential" to all organisms. There are many that lack it entirely, particularly among the bacteria. 

There are also more complex organisms that lack it, because they are entirely anaerobic, and the KREBS CYCLE is only useful during aerobic metabolism. (For the nit-pickers -- yes, I know that the cycle is used for anapleurotic reactions and other reactions that provide metabolic precursors for other processes, and that some of these anaerobes have components of the cycle, but I am talking about the overall cycle and its primary function in aerobic cells, as the clue clearly implies.) 	A good example is Giardia, a protozoan parasite that I bet some of you have had an unfortunate encounter with. IT is metabolically active only in your lower gut, which is anaerobic. There are many others. 

For those who claim this is too specialized or arcane: That is your non-science bias speaking. The KC is taught in every high-school biology class, although I would hope they refer to it primarily as either the tricarboxylic cycle or the citric acid cycle.

@Matt
Eponym, not namesake.
Once upon a time, no one (except word nerds) knew the word "eponym", but everyone knew "namesake". A namesake was something or someone which/who had been named after something/someone else. Vladimir Guerrero Jr. is his father's namesake. The guillotine was Dr. Guillotin's namesake. A regular human trying to refer to someone for whom a thing or person was named would mumble, "You know, the guy whom that was named for." Or sometimes, mistakenly, "namesake."
So far, so clear. Then someone started using "eponym". Mostly correctly, to mean "the person/thing for which something else was named."
But tossed into the raging torrent of demotic speech, both words are now losing their own meanings and blurring. I know -- what a prescriptivist thing to say! I don't care what names you call me. 
These words are not identical, make a useful distinction when used correctly, and should be saved. The /demos/ is /not/ always right.
OK, descriptivists, have at it!

@Helen Wright
I am so sorry you were belittled. I also had teachers who belittled struggling students. I never knew how to react. Those students tended to avoid interacting with the rest of us, and I could certainly understand why. I remember one child ridiculed by a teacher in the 8th grade because he had written the answers to all ten quiz questions as, "I dont no." I'll never forget her tone of voice or that I could not see his face.

In a different part of the country, while I was in a grad program for non-traditional students, I worked as a math tutor for fellow students, mostly teachers of high school humanities returning to school to fulfill requirements for a Master's. A couple had math trauma so strong they would not even pick up a pencil during our sessions. I did not know how to reach them. Today, if I had the chance, I would use more manipulatives, concrete objects that let you see and feel what happens when you do something like square a number.

Part of the crime here is aesthetic. I remember in high school getting marked down because I drew all my graph problems on a single graph, each in a different color, because I thought the combination of curves was beautiful. I suspect some teachers saw math as something to be conquered by brute force, and if you didn't do it that way you weren't serious enough.

@Helen Wright

Very thought provoking post.  

The "knee jerk reaction of anxiety and distress" is so sad to me.

Although math came pretty easy to me, literature and poetry definitely did not.  And yet a poem, while not something I feel a great desire to unravel, doesn't fill me with anxiety and distress.

And I think it's because mathematics at the school level is black and white, right or wrong.  There is no room for interpretation.  There is always a single answer, or a single set of answers, which are true, and everything else is false.

In literature, however, is not so black and white.  In high school English we read e.e. cummings "Buffalo Bill's".   I was a devout Christian at the time, and I took "Jesus he was a handsome man" to mean that cummings had momentarily stopped talking about Buffalo Bill, and was saying that Jesus was a real hunk.

I said that, out loud, in class.  No one mocked me, as they should have.  No one scoffed, which would have been appropriate.  No one registered a bit of disagreement, although I was utterly asinine.  Even the teacher said, "That's an interesting interpretation", even though upon reflection I thought I should have been beet red for saying something so obviously stupid.

So I think you guys are onto something--there's something so final about math, and if I were as incompetent at math as I was a literature, it would have gone harder for me.

There are two sides to every story and I thought maybe the other side needed to state theirs on this thread. Unfortunately, I'm not really inclined to write a lot.  But I have a story to add that demonstrates the other side of several of the posts with specific examples given.  

When I was 11 or 12, I was given an assignment to write an essay.  I believe this was the first time I was assigned to write, rather than a story or a report, nonfiction based on beliefs or experiences. A few days after submitting my essay about how to build a snowman, the teacher read it to the class as an example of how one shouldn't write. I was humiliated.

Perhaps I was motivated to learn to write better. I definitely found it extremely difficult to write after that experience. Unless I feel strongly about my subject, I can rarely bother to put my thoughts in words. This made it difficult to get through college. It makes writing a comment such as this require more time than I usually feel is worth it.
